thread.title: At least Fenway Park has baseball’s speediest WiFi - Local news
thread.title_full: At least Fenway Park has baseball’s speediest WiFi - Local news

author: boston.com
title: At least Fenway Park has baseball’s speediest WiFi - Local news
text:
Fenway Park selfie-takers, you’re going to love this.
Red Sox fans disappointed in their team’s performance this season can at least claim bragging rights to the speediest Wifi in the major leagues, according to a BetaBoston report.
Related Link Get today’s headlines right in your inbox Fenway Park has the fastest upload and dowload speeds in the league, reveals a new survey from RootMetrics. Fenway, which upgraded its WiFi system this past summer, was 22 percent faster than its closest competitor, Detroit’s Comerica Park.
Advertisement - Continue Reading Below RootMetrics measured how fast baseball fans can check e-mail, upload videos, and use apps from inside Fenway Park during a Red Sox-White Sox game in July.
Read the full story at BetaBoston .
10 things you didn’t know about Fenway Park :
Previous -- of -- Next Fenway Park was built on an actual dump, and it was completed in one year—though the left-field and right-field bleachers were not yet built when it opened. The stadium was one of the largest in the league back in 1912. Susan Walsh / AP Previous -- of -- Next Fenway Park was buried in snow along with the rest of Boston last winter—the snow completely overtook the seats at one point. Groundskeepers had to resort to covering the snow in black sand to get it to melt in time for the start of the season. Jessica Rinaldi / The Boston Globe Previous -- of -- Next The lights at Fenway that illuminate the entire neighborhood were installed in 1947. In that same year, ads were removed from the Green Monster, and it was painted green (it was blue and white before that). The Boston Globe Archives Previous -- of -- Next The right-field foul pole was named after Johnny Pesky in 2006 at a dedication ceremony on the former Sox player’s 87th birthday. The left-field foul pole was named after former Red Sox player Carlton Fisk in 2005, since his famous home run in Game 6 of the 1975 World Series made contact with it. Yoon S. Byun / The Boston Globe Previous -- of -- Next On the roof of Fenway, parallel to the third baseline, a garden grows more than 3,000 pounds of produce. The garden was installed and launched by Green City Growers just in time for the 2015 season. Jeff Gilbert / Green City Growers Previous -- of -- Next Advertisement Previous -- of -- Next The red seat in the sea of green bleachers in right field marks the spot where Ted Williams’s 1946 record-setting home run landed — 502 feet from home plate. Earlier this year, Sox slugger David Ortiz expressed doubt over whether or not Williams actually hit the ball that far. Barry Chin / The Boston Globe Previous -- of -- Next After a year of construction, Fenway Park opened on April 20, 1912, with the first home game against the New York Highlanders. The Sox went on to win the World Series that year, and the park was on its way to becoming the iconic Boston landmark it is today. Photo courtesy of the National Baseball Hall of Fame Previous -- of -- Next The trees on Yawkey Way are planted in the same soil used for the infield at Fenway. John Tlumacki / The Boston Globe Previous -- of -- Next The Morse code on the scoreboard translates to the initials of former Sox owners Thomas A. Yawkey and Jean R. Yawkey. The Boston Globe Archives Previous -- of -- Next The bullpen at Fenway used to be in foul territory along the right outfield. In 1940, when the right-field seating was re-done, the bullpen was moved to its current position up against the right field wall near the bleachers. Jessica Rinaldi / The Boston Globe Previous -- of -- Next Advertisement
